3.text:
3 (a)  
Answer: Any two odd primes added correctly  
Marks: 1  
Part marks and guidance:  
• 1 AO2.1a  
• Example: 3 + 5 = 8  

3 (b)  
Answer: An odd integer squared with correct result  
Marks: 1  
Part marks and guidance:  
• 1 AO2.1a  
• Example: 5² = 25

M1 for 450 × 4 oe (using percentages or decimals)

6 (a)

7 (a)

8.text:
8 (a)  
Answer: 8  [3 marks]  
• 2 AO1.3a, 1 AO3.1b  

Marking instructions (award M marks as appropriate):  
• M1 for dividing by 3 or 13  
• M1 for dividing by the remaining factor  
• M1 for multiplying 3 by 13  
• M1 for dividing by 39, or for listing multiples of 39  

(b)  
Answer: Any three valid answers  [3 marks]  
• B1 for each (e.g. 2, 7, 23)  
• 1 AO1.1, 2 AO3.1a  

If 0 marks scored, instead award SC1 for at least 3 primes and 3 squares seen.

9.text:
9 (a)  
• Answer: 2  
• B1 for 2 correct  

  Prism            | Number of faces | Number of edges | Number of vertices  
  Triangular (3 sides)    5                 9                  6    (1 AO1.1)  
  Rectangular (4 sides)   6                12                  8    (1 AO2.1a)  
  Pentagonal (5 sides)    7                15                 10  
  Hexagonal (6 sides)     8                18                 12  

(b)  
• 300 (edges) (1 mark)  
• 200 (vertices) (1 mark)  
• 2 AO2.1a  

(c)  
• F = N + 2 (or equivalent) (2 marks)  
  – 1 AO2.3a  
  – 1 AO2.3b  
• B1 for N + 2 (without a subject)  
• Condone for B1 a correct word formula

10.text:
10 (a) (i) Positive correlation  
• 1 mark  
• 1 AO1.1  
• Condone “positive” or correct description (e.g. “As the temperature increases, more ice creams are sold”).  

10 (a) (ii) Correct reason, for example:  
• “He sold far more ice creams than you would expect him to for a 20 °C day.”  
• 1 mark  
• 1 AO2.3a  

10 (b) (i) 75–95  
• 1 mark  
• 1 AO1.3a  

10 (b) (ii) 140–170  
• 1 mark  
• 1 AO1.3a  

10 (b) (iii) “The (b)(i) prediction is more reliable, as it is within the range of the given data.”  
• 2 marks  
• 1 AO2.1b, 1 AO2.4a  
• B1 for identifying the (b)(i) prediction with a partial reason.  

10 (c) “No, because there may be other factors involved.”  
• 2 marks  
• 1 AO2.5a, 1 AO3.4b  
• B1 for “No” with a partial reason.

11.text:
11 (a)  
Answer: 45 000  
Marks: 2  
Part marks and guidance (2 AO1.3a):  
• M1 for 50 000 × 0.9 soi, or 50 000 – 5 000  

(b)  
Answer: Total value of goods sold in May was £32 805, which is less than £35 000  
Marks: 3  
Part marks and guidance (3 AO2.2):  
• M2 for 50 000 (or 45 000) × 0.9 used three times (or two times) soi, or decreasing by 10% three times  
  OR  
• M1 for 45 000 × 0.9 or 45 000 – 4 500  
  – Implied by 36 450 and 32 805  
  – Implied by 40 500  

(c)  
Answer: 8[%] with correct working  
Marks: 5  
Part marks and guidance (3 AO1.3b, 2 AO3.1d):  
• B4 for answer 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with correct working  
  OR  
• M3 for 1.2 × [0].9 oe  
  or for (100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 – 100 000)/100 000  
  OR  
• M2 for 1.2 and [0].9  
  OR  
• M1 for 1.2 or [0].9  

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for answer 8[%] with no working or insufficient working.  
If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 108[%] or 1.08 or [0].08 with no working or insufficient working.  

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M3 or an alternative convincing approach.  

Throughout, percentage calculations may be performed in stages, e.g. 120% by adding 20%.  
• For example, 100 000 × 1.2 × [0].9 or 120 000 × [0].9.  
• For example, 100 000 × 1.2 implied by 120 000.

12.text:
12 (a)  
Answer: 6  
Marks: 2 (2 AO1.3a)  
• M1 for 3x = 18  

12 (b)  
Answer: –3, –5  
Marks: 3 (3 AO1.3a)  
• M2 for (x + 3)(x + 5) seen or implied in a table  
  OR  
• M1 for (x ± 3)(x ± 5) seen, or for a pair of factors giving two correct terms  
• B1 for correct solutions (FT their quadratic factors)

Part marks and guidance:

• M1 for their “5” × their “10”  
• SC2 for 42 or for area calculation leading to incorrect answer

15.text:
Question 15

(a)  
Answer: 800  
Marks: 2  
• 1 AO1.3b  
• 1 AO3.1c  
Method mark:  
M1 for unitary work, e.g. 1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours  

(b)  
Answer: 30 minutes (or equivalent)  
Marks: 4  
• 2 AO2.1a  
• 2 AO3.1d  
Method marks:  
• M1 for 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour  
• M1 for 5 people do 1000 letters in 2 hours  
• M1 for 4 people do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours  
(FT from their rate in (a) throughout)

(c)  
Marks: 2  
• 1 AO3.4a  
• 1 AO3.5  
B1 for a correct comment on the reasonableness of her assumption (e.g. “She has assumed that ‘all day’ means ‘for 24 hours’, but it is not reasonable for them to work without a break.”)  
B1 for a correct comment on the effect this has on the answer (e.g. “They can’t work at that rate for that long, so her answer is an over-estimate.”)

18.text:
18 (a)  
• The first error is in step 2: −3x − 2x = −5x, not −x as given.  
• 2 marks (2 AO2.5a)  
  – B1 for identifying step 2  
  – B1 for explaining the error  

(b)  
• [x² + 4x + x + 4 = x² − 3x − 2x + 6]  
  x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6  
  5x + 4 = −5x + 6  
  10x + 4 = 6  
  10x = 2  
  x = 1/5  
• 2 marks (2 AO1.3a)  
  – M1 for an attempt to correct the solution in line with their answer to (a)

19.text:
Question 19

Answer:  
(2a + 1) / 4  

Marks: 4  
• 1 mark (AO1.3b)  
• 2 marks (AO3.1b)  
• 1 mark (AO3.2)  

Marking guidance:  
• M1 for correctly summing a + 2 + 3a + 3 + 4a – 1  
• M1 for collecting like terms  
• M1 for dividing their “8a + 4” by 4
